verses.text: They came to the other side of the sea, to the region of the Gerasenes.
verses.comment: The Gerasenes may also be referred to as Gadarenes in some manuscripts. This sets the stage for Jesus' miraculous actions among the Gentiles, showing His mission extends to all peoples (cf. Matt. 28:19).

verses.text: As soon as Jesus stepped out of the boat, a man with an unclean spirit came from the tombs to meet Him.
verses.comment: The term 'unclean spirit' refers to a demon. Meeting Jesus immediately shows the spiritual authority of Christ over darkness (cf. 1 John 3:8).

verses.text: This man lived among the tombs, and no one could bind him anymore, not even with chains.
verses.comment: Living among tombs signified ritual uncleanness (Num. 19:16). The man's uncontrollable strength demonstrates the destructive nature of demonic oppression.

verses.text: He had often been bound with shackles and chains, but he tore the chains apart and broke the shackles to pieces; no one had the strength to subdue him.
verses.comment: His superhuman strength is a further indication of demonic possession. Only Jesus can truly liberate and heal such brokenness.

verses.text: Night and day among the tombs and in the mountains he was always crying out and cutting himself with stones.
verses.comment: Self-harm is shown here as a consequence of demonic influence. In a spiritual sense, this foreshadows Christ who would bear the wounds for our healing (Isa. 53:5).

verses.text: When he saw Jesus from a distance, he ran and bowed down before Him.
verses.comment: Even the demons recognize Christ's divine authority, as shown by his immediate act of homage. This prefigures Philippians 2:10-11, where every knee shall bow to Jesus.

verses.text: Crying out with a loud voice, he said, 'What have You to do with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beg You by God, do not torment me!'
verses.comment: The demon correctly confesses Jesus' divine identity, 'Son of the Most High God.' This is a revelation of high Christology, affirming Jesus’ status beyond a mere prophet.

verses.text: For Jesus had said to him, 'Come out of the man, you unclean spirit!'
verses.comment: Jesus' command shows His authority over spiritual powers. This is a demonstration of His divinity and unique position to liberate humanity from evil.

verses.text: Then Jesus asked him, 'What is your name?' He replied, 'My name is Legion, for we are many.'
verses.comment: 'Legion' points to a large number (a Roman legion was thousands of soldiers). This shows the depth of the man’s bondage, further highlighting the magnitude of Christ’s deliverance.

verses.text: And he repeatedly begged Jesus not to send them out of the region.
verses.comment: Demons recognize and fear Christ’s authority, begging for mercy. This reveals their complete submission to Jesus’ will.

verses.text: Now a large herd of pigs was feeding there on the hillside.
verses.comment: Pigs, considered unclean under Jewish law (Lev. 11:7), emphasize the Gentile setting. The unclean spirits request to enter unclean animals, which is symbolically significant.

verses.text: The demons begged Him, 'Send us to the pigs, so that we may enter them.'
verses.comment: The demons’ plea underlines that even evil spirits are powerless apart from Christ’s permission.

verses.text: Jesus gave them permission. The unclean spirits came out and entered the pigs, and the herd—about two thousand—rushed down the steep bank into the sea and drowned.
verses.comment: Jesus’ granting of permission emphasizes His sovereign power. The destruction of the pigs is a testimony to the destructive aims of evil, while Jesus brings healing.

verses.text: Those tending the pigs ran away and reported it in the city and countryside, and the people came to see what had happened.
verses.comment: This event caused a great stir among the locals. The deliverance of the man takes priority over the economic loss, a model for prioritizing spiritual healing.

verses.text: They came to Jesus and saw the demon-possessed man, the one who had had the legion, sitting there, clothed and in his right mind; and they were afraid.
verses.comment: The man’s transformation confirms the reality of Jesus’ miracle. Spiritual restoration is also depicted, foreshadowing baptismal renewal (cf. 2 Cor. 5:17).

verses.text: Those who had seen it described what had happened to the demon-possessed man and about the pigs.
verses.comment: Witnesses spread news of the miracle, serving as proto-evangelists. Eyewitness testimony is foundational in apostolic preaching (Acts 1:8).

verses.text: Then the people began to beg Jesus to leave their region.
verses.comment: Fear leads the people to reject Jesus rather than rejoice in the miracle. This shows the complexity of human responses to God's action.

verses.text: As He was getting into the boat, the man who had been possessed by demons begged to go with Him.
verses.comment: Those touched by Christ often desire close discipleship. Such longing foreshadows the call to follow Jesus (Luke 9:23).

verses.text: But Jesus did not let him. He said, 'Go home to your friends and tell them how much the Lord has done for you, and how He had mercy on you.'
verses.comment: Jesus commissions the healed man to proclaim God’s mercy, even before He sends out the Twelve. This is an example of testimony integrated into daily life, a form of lay apostolate.

verses.text: So the man went away and began to proclaim in the Decapolis how much Jesus had done for him. And all were amazed.
verses.comment: The Decapolis was a Gentile region. The first Gentile missionary is a former demoniac, showing God's grace works in unexpected ways.

verses.text: When Jesus had crossed again by boat to the other side, a large crowd gathered around Him, and He stayed by the sea.
verses.comment: The sea often symbolizes chaos. Jesus’ ministries on both shores illustrate His universal outreach.

verses.text: Then one of the synagogue leaders, named Jairus, came. And when he saw Jesus, he fell at His feet.
verses.comment: Jairus' act of humility—falling at the feet of Jesus—shows proper submission to divine authority (cf. Matt. 28:9).

verses.text: He earnestly pleaded, 'My little daughter is dying. Please come and place Your hands on her so that she may be healed and live.'
verses.comment: Jairus requests the laying on of hands—a gesture that later becomes associated with apostolic ministry and sacramental healing (Acts 9:17).

verses.text: So Jesus went with him, and a large crowd followed and pressed around Him.
verses.comment: Crowds thronging Jesus indicate His magnetic pull and earthly ministry, but only personal faith leads to true encounter.

verses.text: And there was a woman who had suffered from bleeding for twelve years.
verses.comment: Twelve years matches Jairus’ daughter’s age (v.42), symbolizing completeness and a parallelism in these miracles.

verses.text: She had endured much under many doctors and had spent all she had, but instead of getting better, she grew worse.
verses.comment: Medical remedies failed her; a sign that only Christ offers true healing. Earthly resources are limited, but Christ’s power is limitless.

verses.text: When she heard about Jesus, she came up behind Him in the crowd and touched His cloak.
verses.comment: Touching the cloak alludes to faith requiring a point of contact. Early Church practice included relic veneration, rooted in New Testament precedent (Acts 19:11-12).

verses.text: For she thought, 'If I just touch His clothes, I will be healed.'
verses.comment: Her inner faith leads her to act, showing the necessity of personal trust in Christ and outward expression.

verses.text: Immediately her bleeding stopped, and she felt in her body that she was healed of her disease.
verses.comment: Immediate healing underscores the power present in Christ’s very person (cf. Ps. 107:20).

verses.text: At once Jesus knew that power had gone out from Him. He turned around in the crowd and asked, 'Who touched My clothes?'
verses.comment: Jesus’ awareness of power going out reveals both His divinity and His close, personal involvement with each believer.

verses.text: His disciples said to Him, 'You see the crowd pressing against You, and yet You ask,
"His disciples said to Him, 'You see the crowd pressing against You, and yet You ask, "Who touched Me?"'"
verses.comment: The disciples focus on the external situation, but Jesus seeks the interior movement of faith. Many are near Christ, but not all touch Him in faith.

verses.text: But He kept looking around to see who had done it.
verses.comment: Jesus’ persistent search is an image of the Good Shepherd seeking the one in need (John 10:14-15).

verses.text: Then the woman, knowing what had happened to her, came and fell down before Him and told Him the whole truth.
verses.comment: The woman’s public confession is reminiscent of confession and the healing it brings (James 5:16).

verses.text: He said to her, 'Daughter, your faith has healed you. Go in peace and be freed from your sickness.'
verses.comment: Jesus calls her 'Daughter,' a term of endearment that reflects adoption into the family of God through faith. ‘Go in peace’ echoes liturgical blessings.

verses.text: While He was still speaking, some people came from the house of the synagogue leader and said, 'Your daughter is dead. Why trouble the Teacher any further?'
verses.comment: News of death comes as hope seems lost. But Jesus can work even in situations that appear hopeless to man.

verses.text: But Jesus, ignoring what they said, told the synagogue leader, 'Do not be afraid; only believe.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ command to faith in the face of death prefigures the Christian hope of resurrection (1 Cor. 15:20-22).

verses.text: He did not allow anyone to come with Him except Peter, James, and John, the brother of James.
verses.comment: Peter, James, and John often accompany Jesus at key moments, hinting at a special role for these apostles.

verses.text: They came to the house of the synagogue leader, and Jesus saw a commotion, with people weeping and wailing loudly.
verses.comment: Professional mourners in Jewish custom signal a recognized death. Jesus enters into the human experience of grief yet brings hope.

verses.text: He went inside and said to them, 'Why are you making a commotion and weeping? The child is not dead but sleeping.'
verses.comment: 'Sleeping' is a biblical metaphor for death, used especially in connection with the hope of resurrection (Dan. 12:2).

verses.text: And they laughed at Him. But after He had put them all outside, He took the child's father and mother and those who were with Him, and went in where the child was.
verses.comment: Christ removes the faithless before performing the miracle, showing the necessity of faith even when God's power is at work.

verses.text: Taking her by the hand, He said to her, 'Talitha koum,' which means, 'Little girl, I say to you, get up.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ use of the Aramaic emphasizes the historicity and tenderness of this moment. Direct, personal command is a hallmark of Christ’s miracles.

verses.text: Immediately the girl got up and began to walk, for she was twelve years old. And they were utterly amazed.
verses.comment: Resurrection themes run throughout the Gospels. Jesus’ authority over death prefigures His own Resurrection and the final raising of the dead (John 5:28-29).

verses.text: He strictly charged them that no one should know about this, and told them to give her something to eat.
verses.comment: The command for secrecy is part of the Messianic Secret motif in Mark. Jesus’ provision for the girl’s care shows concern for both body and soul—a holistic, incarnational approach reflected throughout the ministry of the Church.
